content: I'd like to add cover art if there are no objections.
The problem statement is truncated after "11+E" when rendered in the real IDE...

Aaaah, Befunge :-)

Good idea to alter the spec, existing implementations are easy enough to come by.

As is usual for this kind of constrained system, I'd suggest mentioning how integers on the stack behave. (could be as short as "they're signed/unsigned 8-bit with rollover")

Very good counterpoint to the recent influx of useless ASCII art puzzles we've been having recently.

Yay.
Could you tell how the subtraction is done?
this reminded me of Core War. If only there was several programs fighting in the grid...

I've never heard of Core War. I just did some reading on it, and it's a neat idea. For those who don't get the reference, CGFunge is almost a pure subset of a real programming language, Befunge. I have changed most of the characters used, and have also changed the behavior very slightly so that you can't just use a direct copy of an existing Befunge interpreter.

Your comment has my head spinning with possibilities. It sounds like a somewhat more advanced form of the old Sega Dreamcast game, ChuChu Rocket. That could really be fun, and I think there's potential for at least one puzzle based on that idea. I'm going to chew on it a bit more.

I could even see such a beast making a cool multi-player contest.
I assume you want me to clarify the order of the operands in the subtraction operation? If so, then I have made the requested change. Thanks.

I had previously stated "positive integers". I have changed this to "integers in the range [0 - 255]". I don't want to talk about rollover. It could cause more confusion than it relieves, and it doesn't come into play in any of the provided tests.
Huh. That's pretty strange. It doesn't do that for me. I just double-checked. What browser?

I have the problem in FF and in Chrome in the Training section:
https://www.codingame.com/training/community/cgfunge-interpreter
https://www.codingame.com/ide/puzzle/cgfunge-interpreter

And I noticed that I only have the problem in the french version of the site.
Ah, must've missed the "positive", sorry about that.
It's now soundly-specified. I'd suggest adding a simple unambiguous example (e.g. "52-E") for the more visually minded.
Thanks. I have added an example. Good idea.
